config.title: Parenting self-assessment
config.intro_title: How are you and your child coping?
config.intro_copy:
Parenting can be a wonderful and fulfilling experience. It can also be the hardest thing any of us have to deal with.

This assessment is for parents of babies and pre-school children. It provides practical advice to help with the demands of family life. 

The results will give you an overview of your situation, as well as useful links to information 
tailored to your responses.

a.body: Under three months old
Between three and six months old
Between six and 18 months old
Between 18 months and three years old
Over three years old
It's fine. My baby and I are both doing well
I'm still finding it a bit tricky and uncomfortable
My baby doesn't seem to like it
My breasts are sore
My breasts are really sore with a hot red patch
I'm thinking of changing to bottle feeding
I'm not breastfeeding

q.title: New question
q.body: Do any of the following apply to you? You can pick more than one:

a.body: I'm not getting enough sleep
I feel exhausted all the time
I'm still sore after the birth
I don't have time to eat
I'm overweight
I have unusual bleeding
I'm feeling fine

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you been feeling down or anxious since your child was born?

a.body: No, not at all
Sometimes I feel a bit tired or low, but mostly I'm fine
Sometimes I feel quite down
I feel down almost every day
I feel down and depressed all the time

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you feel about teaching your child to use a potty or toilet?

a.body: My child is already potty trained
My child is potty trained during the day but not at night
I've started potty training. It's not going very well and my child gets upset
I'd like to start potty training but I'm not sure if my child is ready

q.title: New question
q.body: How much time do you spend playing with and talking to your child on an average day?

a.body: None
Less than an hour
One to two hours
Two to three hours
Over three hours

q.title: New question
q.body: Has your child had all the recommended tests and vaccinations?

a.body: Yes, they're completely up to date
They have had some of them
They haven't had any
I don't know

q.title: New question
q.body: How would you describe your relationship with your partner since the birth of your child?

a.body: It's good. We're both happy
It's changed but we're adjusting well
We're arguing a lot more than usual. I'm worried about our relationship
My partner is aggressive and violent towards me
I'm not in a relationship at the moment

q.title: New question
q.body: How would you describe your stress level each day?

a.body: Very high most of the time
Sometimes high
Same as normal
My stress level is generally low

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you feel about starting your child on solid food?

a.body: I've already started. It's going well
I want to start but I'm not sure how to go about it
I've started my child on solid food but they often spit it out
My child is breastfeeding well. I don't want to start weaning yet

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you feel about being back at work, or going back soon?

a.body: It's great. I'm enjoying being back at work
I'd like to know more about my rights at work now I'm a parent
I'm due back soon and I'm worried about choosing the right childcare
I'm worried about money. Can I claim any benefits or tax credits?
I feel nervous about leaving my child
I'm back at work. I'm finding it stressful and tiring
I'm not planning to work in the near future

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you made any of the following changes to your home to protect your child from accidents? You can pick more than one:

a.body: Fitted locks to cupboards and windows
Put medicines, bleach and other harmful substances out of reach
Installed a smoke detector
Fitted a stair gate
Covered electrical sockets
None of these

q.title: New question
q.body: Is your child eating as healthily as you would like?

a.body: Yes, they eat a healthy, well-balanced diet including five portions of fruit and vegetables a day
They eat well but not enough fruit and vegetables
I have trouble getting them to eat any food
I can't afford healthy food. It costs a lot more than the food I buy
I think my child overeats, especially things like crisps and chocolate
I'm not sure
Very difficult and unpredictable
Often difficult
Sometimes difficult
Not difficult at all

q.title: New question
q.body: If your child is starting school or pre-school soon, how do you feel about it?

a.body: Fine. I've talked to the teachers and they're aware of my child's needs
I'm not sure how to prepare my child for their first day
I'm worried that my child won't settle in
My child isn't about to start school

q.title: New question
q.body: If you’re not planning another pregnancy yet, are you using contraception?

a.body: Yes, I'm already using contraception
I'm breastfeeding so I don't think I need any
I'm not ready to have sex yet so I don't need it
I want to but I'm not sure which type to use
No, I'm not using any

results.ri: Based on your answers today it seems you are doing really well, which is great. You may wish to consider the following:
Based on your answers today it seems you are doing well but having some problems in a few areas. You may wish to consider the following:
Based on your answers today it seems you are finding some things difficult at the moment. You may wish to consider the following:

links.li: The following links may be of interest:

result_items.ri: If you're having problems breastfeeding, speak to your health visitor about one-to-one support.
If you have soreness caused by breastfeeding, get advice from your GP or health visitor as soon as possible.
If either of your breasts are sore, red and hot, speak to your GP immediately.
If you're thinking of changing to bottle feeding, consider combining it with breastfeeding. Speak to your health visitor.
It's usual to feel tired. Ask friends or family to help out so you can rest when you're particularly tired.
Having a new baby can be exhausting, but if you're feeling anxious or depressed speak to your health visitor or GP immediately.
If you're sore from the birth, ask your health visitor for a check-up to make sure you're healing as expected.
Although it can be hard, eating healthily will give you energy. Try preparing some meals when your baby is sleeping and speak to your health visitor about this.
If you want to lose weight, do it safely. Eat a balanced diet and build gentle exercise into your day, such as going for a walk.
If you have any unusual bleeding, see your GP or health visitor as soon as you can for a check-up and advice.
It's normal to feel tired or low sometimes. But if you feel very low, it's important to talk to your health visitor.
If feeling down is affecting your day-to-day life, speak to your GP or health visitor. There's lots they can do to help.
Don't ignore your feelings. If you're feeling down most days, speak to your GP or health visitor as soon as possible.
It's great that your child is potty trained during the day. It's natural for it take longer to be dry at night. This should come with time.
It may be too soon for your child to potty train. Go back to nappies for a few weeks and then start again.
Children are usually ready for potty training when they can tell you that they need to wee or poo in advance of doing it.
Playing encourages your baby's development so increase your playtime to at least an hour a day.
Check with your health visitor which vaccinations your baby may have missed so they can get them.
If there's no medical reason for your child not to have their vaccinations, they should have them soon.
A new baby is a massive change and it's normal for this to affect your relationship.
Many couples have difficulties at this time. But if you're worried, speak to your local branch of Relate (see Useful links).
Domestic violence is a serious offence. For advice, call the free 24-hour helpline on 0808 200 0247.
Bringing up a child on your own has its pressures. If you're struggling, speak to your health visitor.
You're certainly not alone if you feel a bit stressed. But if you feel unable to cope, speak to your GP.
Well done: your stress levels are low, and you're clearly coping very well with being a parent.
Weaning can seem daunting at first. Read our features and if you still have concerns, ask your health visitor for further advice.
If your baby refuses solids, try different foods. At first, make them completely smooth.
Breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months, after which solids should be introduced.
It's important to know your rights in the workplace so that your work fits in with family life.
There are many childcare options available. Take your time to consider what's best for you and your child.
If you're on a low income, you may be entitled to benefits and/or tax credits. See Useful links.
Going back to work can be a big step. Speak to your employer about any concerns you have.
If work is stressful, consider talking to your employer about flexible working.
You've already taken steps to make your home safer. You can also ask your local council's safety officer to advise you.
Your home can be adapted to help prevent accidents. See Useful links for information on how.
Be creative with fruit and vegetables. Include them in the foods your child loves, like pizza and pasta.
Cooking with kids can encourage them to eat. If you'd like more advice, speak to your health visitor.
Read our feature about affordable healthy foods. You can also get advice from your health visitor.
If your child is overeating, speak to your health visitor for advice on healthy eating. See Useful links.
Speak to your health visitor about what sorts of your child should be eating and what to avoid.
If your child's behaviour is sometimes difficult, or getting worse, you may find it helpful to speak to your health visitor about how to deal with it.
Prepare your child for school or pre-school by telling them all about it. Reassure them that it will be fun and take them there for a visit so that they know what to expect.
If you're concerned about your child, speak to someone at the school about your concerns and discuss ways to help them settle in.
It is possible to get pregnant while breastfeeding. Use contraception if you don't want to have another baby.
It's good idea to think about contraception. That way, if you do feel ready for sex, it's already sorted out.
There are many types of contraception available. Your GP, health visitor or local GUM clinic can advise you.

link_items.ri: Read about the benefits of breastfeeding
Keeping fit and healthy after having a baby
Bringing up a child on your own

ib.title: Signs of postnatal depression
ib.body:
Getting depression after a baby is born can be very distressing. There are a number of symptoms. Some symptoms, such as tiredness, irritability or a poor appetite, are normal if you have just had a baby. Usually these are mild and do not stop you leading a normal life. 

If you have postnatal depression, you may be increasingly depressed and despondent. Looking after yourself or the baby may become too much.

It usually occurs two to eight weeks after the birth and in some cases the baby blues don't go away. Sometimes the depression doesn't appear until up to a year after the baby is born.
ib.name: Signs of postnatal depression

ib.title: Potty training
ib.body:
Children get bladder and bowel control when they're physically ready for it, and when they want to be dry and clean. Every child is different, so it's best not to compare your child with others.

It usually takes a little longer to learn to stay dry throughout the night. Most children learn this between the ages of three and five. It's estimated that one in four three year olds and one in six five year olds wet the bed.
ib.name: Potty training

ib.title: Why playing is important
ib.body:
We all know that playing is fun, but it's also the most effective way for children to learn. By playing, children can practise all the skills they'll need as they grow up.

To grow and develop, children need time and attention from someone who is happy to play with them. Gradually, they'll learn to entertain themselves for some of the time.

It can be hard to find time to play with your child when you're busy. Try to find ways of involving your child in what you're doing, even the chores. Children learn from everything they do and everything that's going on around them.
ib.name: Why playing is important

ib.title: More on vaccinations
ib.body:
It's important that your baby has their vaccinations at the right age, to keep the risk of disease and any side effects as low as possible. All childhood vaccinations are free. Your GP or clinic will usually send you an appointment for vaccinations. Here's a quick guide to when vaccinations are due:

  • 2 months: diptheria, tetanus, whooping cough, polio and Hib (DTaP/IPV/Hib) plus pneumococcal and rotavirus
  • 3 months: DTaP/IPV/Hib; meningitis C (Men C) and rotavirus
  • 4 months: DTap/IPV/Hib and pneumococcal
  • 12-13 months: measles, mumps and rubella (MMR), pneumococcal (PCV), Hib/MenC booster.
  • Three years, four months: DTap/IPV; MMR.
ib.name: More on vaccinations

ib.title: Signs of unhealthy stress
ib.body:
Small children take a lot of looking after, but perhaps the most stressful thing is having to cope with everything else in life as well. 

Sometimes you can feel as though life is out of control. If you're a person who likes to be in control and worries about things getting done, this can make you feel tense and frustrated.

Signs of unhealthy stress include:

  • anger
  • depression
  • anxiety
  • panic attacks
  • chest pains
  • dizziness
ib.name: Signs of unhealthy stress

ib.title: Safety for under-fives
ib.body:
Accidents are one of the leading causes of death among children aged between one and five. Every year, about 500,000 children under five go to hospital because of an accident in the home.

Exploring and playing are an essential part of learning and children shouldn't be wrapped in cottonwool. Bumps and bruises are inevitable, but you can do some simple things to make sure your child doesn't get seriously injured.

Find out more about safety for under-fives by following the useful links at the end of this tool.
ib.name: Safety for under-fives

ib.title: More on toddler tantrums
ib.body:
Temper tantrums usually start at around 18 months. They're very common at that age: one in five two-year-olds has a temper tantrum every day. One reason for this is that two year olds really want to express themselves, but find it difficult.

They feel frustrated and the frustration comes out as a tantrum. Once a child can talk more, they're less likely to have tantrums. Tantrums are far less common by about the age of four.
ib.name: More on toddler tantrums

ib.title: School starting dates
ib.body:
Legally, children must start formal education no later than the beginning of the school term following their fifth birthday. Many infant and primary schools admit children to their reception classes when they are four.

If you're offered a school place for your child when they're four, but would rather they started school later in the school year, you can ask the school to defer entry. But you must take the place during that school year. You can't hold it over to the next year.

Schools can only offer a certain number of places, so start looking early. You can get a list of local schools and information about them from your local education department.
ib.name: School starting dates

ib.title: Contraception and breastfeeding
ib.body:
You can get pregnant as little as three weeks after the birth of a baby. This can happen even if you're breastfeeding, and even if you haven't started your periods again.

You can use male and female condoms as soon as you feel ready to have sex. The combined pill, progestogen-only pill and contraceptive implants can be used from 21 days after the birth. However, the combined pill is not recommended if you're breastfeeding, as it can affect your milk supply.

You can usually have a contraceptive injection or start using a diaphragm or cap around six weeks after giving birth. If you used a diaphragm or cap before becoming pregnant, see your GP or family planning clinic to ensure that it still fits correctly, as childbirth and other factors such as weight loss/gain can have a significant effect. An IUD (coil) or IUS can usually be fitted six to eight weeks after giving birth.
ib.name: Contraception and breastfeeding
